title: Verified Purchase
content: Let me preface my comments by stating I am a huge Kristin Hannah fan but prefer her historical novels (looking forward to reading The Women soon). I recently read that a reader felt that Hannah's novels are predictable. This is an unfair comment as positive endings are sorely needed in today's world. In all her works, Hannah does an amazing job of writing from a woman's perspective and following the challenges and difficult choices her female characters face.  I eagerly am looking forward to reading all of her novels

title: Great book.

title: Verified Purchase
content: Annie had been married for twenty years and at the age of 49, her husband announced that he no longer loved her and that he had taken a lover.  He wanted a divorce.  Their daughter of 18 was going to college in the fall.  Annie had given her all to her family, always putting aside her own thoughts and dreams to make them happy.  Devastated, she returns to her hometown of Mystic Lake, OR, tries to pick up the pieces of her life.  She meets Nick, an old friend from high school days and he, having lost his wife to cancer less than a year before, is trying to cope while his daughter of six is having grave issues also trying to deal w/ the loss of her mother.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2016

title: her husband announced that he no longer loved her and that he had taken a lover
content: Annie takes on the care of Izzy during the day and eventually, through love and friendship, Izzy begins to understand the loss and recover.  Nick has turned to alcoholism as a solace but, w/ Annie’s help and the help of AA, he learns that one day at a time he can cope w/ it all.  He falls in love w/ Annie but knows she must return to her home when her husband declares he wants her back.  The story is a good one and I kept an interest to the end.  A happy ending is always a good one.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2024

title: Predictable
content: I loved this book. Having grown up without a mother. It made me remember a lot of what Izzy felt. This story was so well written and happy and sad and poignant all at the same time!

title: Verified Purchase
content: I've read 5 or so of Kristin Hannah's other books and really enjoyed them, especially "Nightingale."  This wasn't her best.  Annie was a completely one-dimensional character.  Her husband was a world class jerk and her daughter was conveniently out of country, so leaving her whole life behind was as easy as turning off the lights in her Malibu home.  No conflict at all.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2024

title: Another great book by Hannah
content: Hannah didn't even throw in a contentious divorce settlement offer or her husband cutting off her credit cards to complicate Annie's life.  So what could have been an interesting journey for a 40ish divorcee unfortunately turned into a formulaic romance novel...because there was nothing to be conflicted about.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: While Annie was NICE, I couldn't relate to her at all: She had no job, no hobbies other than shopping, no pets, no causes dear to her heart...and really no excuses for "fading" away.  They had enough money to afford a beachfront home, she lived in a city with a dozen universities, a few million people and 10,000 things to do...and yet she had no life.  And that's her husband's fault?
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2023

title: Midlife realizations that your dreams are not coming true. What do you do?

title: Verified Purchase

post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2024

title: Disappointed
content: Annie's 1955-like struggle was that she lost herself becoming a perfect wife and mother.  Her husband leaves her and her only child goes to college.  After 20 years of marriage and within only 3 months she somehow finds her true self by reconnecting with a high school lover.  Really?  And then gets pregnant - really?  I found the whole scenario completely depressing - that the heroine decides to fix the past by completely repeating the past with a supposed new found perspective on life that she somehow gained in only 3 months.  Really - that's all life has to offer?  Repeating the same thing over again and hoping this time, it's different - really?
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2012

title: Verified Purchase
content: Perhaps the author should write a book about Izzy.  I found her to be the most fascinating character in the book.

title: First Kristin Hannah read
content: Just finished On Mystic Lake and I did really like it.  This is the first book of hers that I have read and I will be trying out another soon.  This was a good light read that kept me interested and had some great life lessons to think of as well.  Interesting and entertaining to me I finished it in only a few days.  I may have found it more appealing being that I am a mother now, don't think I would have liked it quite as much before I had a child of my own.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2023

title: Verified Purchase
content: One thing I did not like about this book is that it shifts narrator and time without warning and can be a little awkward and confusing.  I mean- I figured it out as I read, but a little space between shifts or a line or new chapter would have been a little better in my opinion.  I like for the book to prepare me for seeing things through a different characters eyes.  It obviously didn't put me off too much though, I am heading to the library today and plan to pick up another one of her novels.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2023
